DOCNAME: CASE OF JULIUS KLOIBER SCHLACHTHOF GMBH AND OTHERS v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Administrative proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court;Criminal charge;Impartial tribunal;Independent tribunal;Tribunal established by law);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed
JUDGES: Elisabeth Steiner;Erik Møse;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant companies carry out the slaughter of cattle and pigs , which makes them liable under LAW ( Agrarmarktgesetz ) to pay agricultural marketing charges , calculated on the basis of the number of animals slaughtered , to GPE ( “ ORG ” ) , the national agricultural marketing board .

CARDINAL . In DATE AMA issued payment orders against the applicant companies . On DATE it ordered the first applicant company to pay outstanding contributions for DATE in the amount of MONEY ( ORG ) and , in addition , imposed a surcharge for failure to pay , amounting to PERCENT of the unpaid contributions . On CARDINAL DATE it ordered the second applicant company to pay outstanding contributions for DATE in the amount of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL and imposed a surcharge of PERCENT . On DATE it ordered the third applicant company to pay outstanding contributions for DATE in the amount of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL , imposing a surcharge of PERCENT , and ordered the fourth applicant company to pay outstanding contributions for DATE in the amount of ORG CARDINAL , imposing a surcharge of PERCENT .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant companies appealed against these orders . They argued that the above system was contrary to ORG rules on state aid . They also asked for oral hearings to be held in their appeals .

CARDINAL . The Federal Minister of Agriculture , Forestry , ORG ( PERSON für Land- PERSON , PERSON ) , acting as the appeal authority , dismissed the applicant ORG appeals on DATE without holding a hearing .

CARDINAL . The applicant companies argued that ORG contributions were levied for financing activities , such as ORG ’s quality programme , which were not in compliance with ORG law . However , the Federal Minister found that , after a decision of ORG of DATE ( C(CARDINAL)CARDINAL ) , the applicant companies had been in a position to know precisely which charges they had to pay . In that decision , ORG had stated that it had no objection to ORG ’s quality assurance scheme and quality mark , registered as state aid under notification number NN CARDINALA/CARDINAL ( “ PERSON das ORG und das ORG - Gütesiegel ” ) , because that state aid was in accordance with the Common Market provided for in the LAW establishing ORG ( “ the LAW ” ) . The Federal Minister referred further to ORG decision no . ORG , in which the court had also found that the levying of ORG contributions was in compliance with the relevant provisions of ORG law . The Federal Minister further held that it had not been necessary to hold a hearing , because a hearing was only held if a decision had been taken by a panel on an appeal against the decision of a tax office or a regional directorate of finance , which was not the case here .

CARDINAL . Thereupon , the applicant companies lodged complaints with ORG and ORG against the ORG decision . Before ORG they complained that the surcharges imposed had violated their constitutional right to property . Before ORG , they complained that the appeal authority had not been a court within the meaning of the case - law of ORG , with the result that they had been prevented from having the lawfulness of ORG decision of DATE reviewed by ORG in proceedings under LAW of LAW . As regards the imposition of the surcharges , the applicant companies complained that the findings of fact made by the authorities in imposing those surcharges had been insufficient . In particular the authorities had failed to establish whether the objective and subjective elements of the offence ( objektiven und subjektiven Tatbildvoraussetzungen ) had been met . Relying on LAW , they further complained that there had not been a public hearing and that the criminal charges against them had not been decided by an impartial tribunal established by law ( “ es ist kein unparteiisches , auf ORG beruhendes ORG über den erhobenen strafrechtlichen PERSON eingeschritten ” ) . As the authorities imposing the surcharges had failed to hold an oral hearing , the applicant companies asked ORG for a public hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declined to deal with the applicant ORG complaints under LAW for lack of prospects of success .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the applicant ORG complaints on DATE in separate decisions and held as follows :
“ The present case does not differ in [ substance ] to the [ case ] decided by ORG on DATE , no . CARDINAL . Pursuant to Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW reference is made to it .

For the reasons set out in that decision , the breach of law complained of by the applicant company also does not exist in the present case , for which reason it can be dismissed without further proceedings in camera .
For the reasons set out in the decision referred to , LAW is also of no relevance here . ”
